heading: Croatian Coasts
description: A PHP themeing project based on designs from a high-end resort chain from Croatia.

sections.caption: Unslpash has always been a good resource, and is usually where I get images for these projects from.
sections.description: I like to begin the research phase by looking at content choices from free resources like Unslpash.com and websites that are similar to the niche I am looking at. In this image, I have added some images and sections taken from different websties to serve as a folder for inspiration.

sections.caption: Eric Meyer knows a lot about CSS, and this is a really good reset. You need a good reset to reduce browser inconsistencies. The link to the reset can be found here.
sections.description: This is the first mockup where I get a layout in place. I've done several of these as practice. This boilerplate contains the basic file structure as well, such as a css folder that contains typography choices, structure, and a css reset so that there are no default styles. Of course, there is some sort of default so you have to make some choices as to what things should look like. In this case, I am using the Meyer CSS reset.

The website layout represents a combination of the content I compiled from Unsplash as well as the inspiration I got from looking at similar sites. I use a simple banner, some call to actions, and an article card grid. Just lists of things arranged in different orders!

sections.caption: This is just a basic PHP router. Nothing to see here. At this point I've added the module folders that contain the css and html. I'll use these to pull in JSON to populate each module.
'The important part is that the code works' - Abraham Lincoln
sections.description: When I was done with the basic layout, I added a little bit of CRUD functionality. Does this site really need it? Not really... but I need the PHP practice. This basically allows you to add and remove article cards. Could be a decent basis for a CMS though! But a regular CMS would be better for this type of project, or no CMS at all! It's just a basic landing page, maybe the owner doesn't need to control everything...

heading: Riche Fashion
description: A research project that implemented design principles found among fashion websites.

sections.heading: Project Goals
sections.content: In this project, I wanted to produce a design that was based on my research of high-end fashion websites. I began by researching various sites like Prada and Gucci to see what visual language they used.

sections.heading: The Research Phase
sections.caption: This is an example of that research
sections.description: From my research, I noticed that the sites I was finding tended to use large images of models to highlight the clothing they were wearing. I knew that image content choice for this site would be one of the most important steps - which is true for almost all sites, but especially true within the context of a fashion company. I took away that I should use minimal text and to communicate through images of the models when possible.

sections.heading: Unslpash is king!
sections.caption: This is an example of that research
sections.description: Unsplash.come is a great resource for finding image content, and I decided to stick with images similar to what I was finding on sites like Prada and Gucci. I wanted bold colors and fashionable design choices to be the main focus of the site. I knew from the beginning that I wanted to stick with white background and black text for the pages, so finding images that had high color contrast was really important, as I didn't want to take away from the content by making the text or background of the page to be the focal point - in this project at least.

sections.heading: The Style Tile Phase
sections.caption: This is an example of that research
sections.description:
Just like with this portfolio and the hotel projects, style tiles act as an important step in the design and development process. Tiles are a loosely created board of samples of what the design could look like. Tiles are a cheap and efficient way of presenting options to the client without having to go down the more costly route of jumping right to code mockups.

User feedback is really important to strengthen the relationship between the client and the design and development team and create the best final product cheaply and quickly. I decided to present some elements such as buttons, item lists and cards, and landing elements to my mentors.

sections.heading: The First Draft
sections.caption: This is an example of that research
sections.description:
With the userfeedback from the style tile phase in hand, I created the first version of the layout. I was pleased with the direction of the project, and was keeping many of the design choices I learned from other websites in mind.

This still left another step to go: I had to create other pages, including the item lists and detail lists. I knew going in that I would have to learn quite a bit about databases and JSON - and accessing those items to show on the page. I was trying to make an ecommerce site without unique items and filters. It wouldn't be a cake walk.
